intro: Manilkara remotifolia, commonly known as the wild cocoa tree, is a tropical evergreen species native to Central and South America. It belongs to the Sapotaceae family and is characterized by its large, glossy leaves and clusters of yellowish-green flowers. The plant produces edible fruits that contain a sticky, aromatic pulp and a single seed, which is used in traditional medicine. Its latex is also valued for its industrial applications, including the production of adhesives and varnishes. The tree plays an important ecological role in its native habitats, supporting diverse wildlife and contributing to forest biodiversity.
